tn.text: Hannah recites a song to Yahweh. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
"I have great joy"
"because of who Yahweh is" or "because Yahweh is so great"
A horn is a symbol of strength. AT: "I am now strong" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Hannah continues to recite a song to Yahweh. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: there is no rock like our God
tn.text: This is another way of saying that God is strong and faithful. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This is a rock large enough to hide behind or to stand on and so be high above one's enemies.
Hannah continues to recite a song to Yahweh. She speaks as if other people were listening to her. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
"no arrogant words"
This can be stated in active form. AT: "he weighs people's actions" or "he understands why people act as they do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: The bow of the mighty men are broken
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) the bows themselves are broken or 2) the men who carry the bows are prevented from acting. AT: "Mighty bowmen are kept from acting"

tn.ref: The bow of the mighty men are broken
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "Yahweh breaks the bows of the mighty men" or "Yahweh can make even the strongest of people weak" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: those who stumble put on strength like a belt
tn.text: This metaphor means they will no longer stumble, but their strength will remain with them as tightly as a belt. AT: "he will make those who stumble strong" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This is the general term for putting something around one's waist to prepare for work.
Hannah continues to recite a song to Yahweh. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
"gives birth to seven children"
"becomes weak and sad and lonely"
Hannah continues to recite a song to Yahweh. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: Yahweh kills ... brings to life ... brings down ... raises up ... makes some people poor ... some rich ... humbles ... lifts up
tn.text: Yahweh is in control of everything. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])
Hannah continues to recite a song to Yahweh. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: out of the dust ... from the ash heap
tn.text: These are metaphors for the lowest position in society. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
people who do not have the things that they need
Hannah continues to recite a song to Yahweh. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: guard the feet of his faithful people
tn.text: Here "feet" is a metonym for the way a person walks, which in turn is a metaphor for the way a person decides how to live his life. AT: "keep his faithful people from making foolish decisions" or "enable his faithful people to make wise decisions" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: the wicked will be put to silence in darkness
tn.text: This polite way of saying that Yahweh will kill the wicked can be stated in active form. AT: "Yahweh will put the wicked to silence in darkness" or "Yahweh will put the wicked in the dark and silent world of the dead" (See: [[: en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])

tn.ref: the wicked will be put to silence
tn.text: The words "be put to silence" are an idiom for "be made silent." This can be stated in active form. AT: "Yahweh will make them silent" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"because he is strong"
Hannah continues to recite a song to Yahweh. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: Those who oppose Yahweh will be broken
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "Yahweh will break those who oppose him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This idiom means "defeated." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an idiom that means everywhere. AT: "the whole earth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: exalt the horn of his anointed
tn.text: A horn is a symbol of strength. See how you translated similar words in [[:en:bible:notes:1sa:02:01|2:1]]. AT: "he will make the leader he has chosen stronger than his enemies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

This speaks of the person that Yahweh chose and empowered for his purposes as if Yahweh had anointed the person with oil. This can be stated in active form. AT: "the one he has anointed" or "the one he has chosen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
When people would offer animals as sacrifices, they would first burn the animal's fat and then boil the meat and eat it.
"did not listen to Yahweh" or "did not obey Yahweh"
A custom is an action that people regularly do.

tn.ref: into the pan, or kettle, or cauldron, or pot
tn.text: These are containers in which food could be cooked. If your language does not have separate words for these items it can be stated more generally. AT: "into whatever the people were cooking the meat in"
a small metal container for boiling and cooking
a large, heavy metal container for boiling and cooking
a large, heavy metal container for boiling and cooking
a clay container for cooking
When people would offer animals as sacrifices, they would first burn the animal's fat and then boil the meat, give some to the priest, and eat the rest.
"They even did something worse than that. Before"
The person who actually did the burning can be made explicit. AT: "the man who was sacrificing took his sacrifice to the priests and the priests burned" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: Give meat to roast for the priest
tn.text: "Give me some meat so I can give it to the priest so he can roast it"
cook over a fire
cooked in water
not cooked
The young men did not like Yahweh's instructions regarding the offering and paid no attention to them.

tn.ref: because of the request she made of Yahweh
tn.text: Hannah had asked Yahweh for a baby and promised him that she would give the baby to serve in the temple.
This means where Yahweh could see him and Samuel could learn about Yahweh.
This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. AT: "It is terrible that you do such things!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. AT: "there is certainly no one who can speak for him." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"ask Yahweh to have mercy on him"
This is a metonym in which the voice represents the person. AT: "their father" or "what their father said" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This phrase usually means a prophet of Yahweh. AT: "a man who hears and tells words from God"

tn.ref: Did I not reveal myself ... house?
tn.text: This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. AT: "You should know that I revealed myself ... house." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
The word "house" is a metonym for the people who lived in the house. AT: "the family of your ancestor" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Aaron

tn.ref: to go up to my altar, and to burn incense
tn.text: This refers to making an offering to Yahweh.

tn.ref: to wear an ephod before me
tn.text: The words "wear an ephod" are a metonym for the work of the priests who wear the ephod. AT: "to do what I had commanded the priests to do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The man of God continues to speak to Eli.

tn.ref: Why, then, do you scorn my sacrifices ... live?
tn.text: This rhetorical question is a rebuke. It can be translated as a statement. AT: "You should not scorn my sacrifices ... where I live." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"the place where my people bring offerings to me"

tn.ref: making yourselves fat with the best of every offering
tn.text: The best part of the offering was to be burned up as an offering to Yahweh, but the priests were eating it.

The word "house" is a metonym for the people who lived in the house. Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:1sa:02:27|2:27]]. AT: "the family of your ancestor"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This is an idiom that means "live in obedience to me." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: Far be it from me to do this
tn.text: "I will certainly not allow your family to serve me forever"

tn.ref: those who despise me will be lightly esteemed
tn.text: The words "lightly esteemed" is an ironic euphemism for "greatly despised." This can be stated in active form. AT: "I will lightly esteem those who despise me" or "I will greatly despise those who despise me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_irony]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"Listen carefully to what I am about to say" or "What I am about to say is very important"

tn.ref: I will cut off your strength and the strength of your father's house
tn.text: The words "cut off ... strength" are probably a euphemism for the death of strong, young men; the words "your father's house" are a metonymy for "your family." AT: "I will kill you and all strong, young male descendants in your family" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"be any old men" or "be any men who grow old"
"cause you to lose your eyesight" or "cause you to go blind"

tn.ref: I will raise up ... a faithful priest
tn.text: This is an idiom. AT: "I will cause a man to become priest" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an idiom. AT: "to serve me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: what is in my heart and in my soul
tn.text: "what I want him to do and what I tell him to do"

tn.ref: I will build him a sure house
tn.text: Here "house" is an idiom used for "descendants." AT: "I will ensure that he always has a descendant who serves as high priest" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
the faithful priest whom God will raise up

tn.ref: so I can eat a piece of bread
tn.text: Here "piece of bread" is used for "food. "AT: "so I can have something to eat" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
